abstract: The New Journalism is a 1973 [[anthology|anthology]] of journalism edited by [[Tom Wolfe|Tom Wolfe]] and E. W. Johnson. The book is both a [[manifesto|manifesto]] for a new type of journalism by Wolfe, and a collection of examples of [[New Journalism|New Journalism]] by American writers, covering a variety of subjects from the frivolous (baton twirling competitions) to the deadly serious (the [[Vietnam War|Vietnam War]]). The pieces are notable because they do not conform to the standard [[dispassionate and even-handed|Objectivity (journalism)]] model of [[journalism|journalism]]. Rather they incorporate [[literary devices|Literary technique]] usually only found in fictional works.
title: The New Journalism

abstract: How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild, and Got a Life is a [[young adult novel|young adult fiction]] by Kaavya Viswanathan, who wrote it just after she graduated from high school. Its 2006 debut was highly publicized while she was enrolled at [[Harvard University|Harvard University]], but the book was withdrawn after it was discovered that portions had been [[plagiarized|plagiarism]] from several sources, including the works of [[Salman Rushdie|Salman Rushdie]] and [[Meg Cabot|Meg Cabot]]. Viswanathan apologized and said any similarities were "completely unintentional and unconscious." All shelf copies of Opal Mehta were ultimately recalled and destroyed by the publisher, and Viswanathan's contract for a second book was canceled.
title: How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild, and Got a Life

abstract: Mr. Tickle is the first book in the [[Mr. Men|Mr. Men]] series by [[Roger Hargreaves|Roger Hargreaves]], published 10 August 1971.
title: Mr. Tickle

abstract: 20th Century Ghosts is American author [[Joe Hill|Joe Hill (writer)]]'s first published book-length work. A collection of [[short stories|short story]], it was first published in October 2005 in the United Kingdom and released in October 2007 in the United States.
title: 20th Century Ghosts

abstract: Mr. Midnight is a children's horror fiction book series written by Jim Aitchison under the pseudonym of [[James Lee|James Lee (writer)]]. The series is published by Angsana Books, Flame Of The Forest Publishing. There are currently 115 books in the series, including 19 Special Edition titles, with more being written and released around every two to four months. It has been translated into Burmese, Malay, Indonesian, simplified Chinese, and traditional Chinese.
title: Mr. Midnight

abstract: The 85 Ways to Tie a Tie () is a book by [[Thomas Fink|Thomas Fink]] and [[Yong Mao|Yong Mao]]. The authors were [[research fellow|research fellows]] at Cambridge University’s [[Cavendish Laboratory|Cavendish Laboratory]]. It was published by [[Fourth Estate|HarperCollins#Imprints]] on Nov 4, 1999, and subsequently published in nine other languages.
title: The 85 Ways to Tie a Tie

abstract: The Biographies of Exemplary Women () is a book compiled by the [[Han Dynasty|Han Dynasty]] scholar [[Liu Xiang|Liu Xiang (scholar)]] c. 18 BC. It includes 125 biographical accounts of exemplary women in ancient China, taken from early Chinese histories including [[Chunqiu|Spring and Autumn Annals]], [[Zuozhuan|Zuozhuan]], and the [[Records of the Grand Historian|Records of the Grand Historian]]. The book served as a standard [[Confucianist|Confucianist]] textbook for the moral education of women in traditional China for two millennia.
title: Biographies of Exemplary Women

abstract: Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien (1887–1915) by [[Adolf Engler|Adolf Engler]] and [[Karl Anton Prantl|Karl Anton Prantl]] is a complete revision of plant families down to generic level and often even further. As such it forms part of the [[Engler system|Engler system]] of [[plant taxonomy|plant taxonomy]].
title: Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien

abstract: In Defense of Global Capitalism (in [[Swedish|Swedish language]]: Till världskapitalismens försvar) is a book by [[Swedish|Sweden]] writer [[Johan Norberg|Johan Norberg]] promoting [[economic globalization|economic globalization]] and [[free trade|free trade]]. The book was originally published in May 2001 by the Swedish think tank [[Timbro|Timbro]]. Since then, a number of translations into other languages have followed.
title: In Defense of Global Capitalism
